newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary's first mortgage bank to be set up in July.
newsitem.headline: Hungary's first mortgage bank to be set up in July.

text.p: Hungary will revive a pre-war financial institution by setting up a mortgage bank, probably in the middle of July, the Mortgage Bank Preparatory Rt (MBP) said on Thursday.

"One of the most important targets (of the mortgage bank) is to extend long-term agricultural loans," MBP Chairman Istvan Tompe told a news conference, adding that agricultural enterprises don't yet have access to long-term mortgage loans.
Mortgage banks were an integral part of Hungary's financial system until communists came to power after World War II.

The new bank, Land Credit and Mortgage Bank (LCMB) would sell its mortgage bonds on the domestic and foreign markets, extend mortage loans to medium-size and large agricultural enterprises mainly for maturities over five years.
It would buy and sell such loans on the secondary market, and is also likely to enter the Budapest Stock Exchange with its securities, Tompe said.

MBP hopes that its founders, five Hungarian banks including Postabank and Kereskedelmi (K&H), would buy LCMB's shares and MBP is also engaged in negotiations about ownership with other Hungarian banks with substantial branch networks, Tompe said.
He added that MBP would like the government to hold 50 percent or slightly less of LCMB's shares temporarily as its initial participation would increase customer confidence.
The registered capital of the mortgage bank will be at least three billion forints ($16.6 million), but MBP encourages the owners to raise four billion forints, Tompe said.
An MBP official said that LCMB was likely to extend loans of 15 billion to 17 billion forints next year.
MBP said that the development of Hungary's real estate and land market is hindered by a slow registration system and by the law which does not allow mortgaging of leased land.
Some 70 percent of Hungary's farmland is leased, Tompe said.
Foreigners and companies are not allowed to buy land in Hungary.
-- Sandor Peto, Budapest newsroom (36 1) 327 4040 ($ = 181.0 Hungarian Forints)
